instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps rebooting
threads.message:
This board had liquid damage only in one spot that I could find. <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> was the only component I could fine where there was any liquid damage. I removed that cap and I saw that the pad on Pin 2 was completely gone so I had to put the cap on pin 1 and put some solder onto the probe point next to it. Now the fan spins and the cpu gets warm but for some reason when I have the screen or something plugged in I will see the screen flash as if it turns on but then it will shut off and the fan stops spinning then it repeats over and over.

When I have no external components plugged in the fan will spin for about 10 seconds then shut off and repeat again.

<CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> was surprisingly the only component that had any signs of liquid damage. I ultrasonic'd the board but still the issue remains.

When I first received the board the fan would spin for 1 second then shut off and it does that also when I remove <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> from the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps rebooting
threads.message: Corroded trace to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pin13 and or <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps rebooting
threads.message:
Also I made a mistake in the previous post. Pin 1 was actually the one that had the pad gone and I had to solder to Prboe 768. 
There is continuity from Pin 13 of <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> to Pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR>.
There is also continuity from Pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> to Pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>.
Do you know why Pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> leads to the <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> chip when the schematic shows that Pin 1 should be connected to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps rebooting
threads.message: Can you not see on the schematic that pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> goes to pin 13 on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>? Is the trace between <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> pin 1 and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pin 15 in tact?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps rebooting
threads.message:
Sorry I didn't notice it connected to pin 13. 
But Pin 1 was gone from the pad so I have Pin 1 soldered to Probe 768 and Pin 2 is on its original pad. 
I have continuity from Probe 768 all the way to Pin 15 of <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keeps rebooting
threads.message: No idea, replace <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and check traces around it. Also of course the common <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 should be checked.
